comment: Maybe all it needs to be conscious is a javascript like event loop. At the moment it's a function that returns what it thinks is the correct answer to a prompt but that prompt is the source of activation. The life force or vitality is injected into it by the user's intent. Embed GPT4 inside a loop that responds to the set of outside-world events fed into it from some suite of sensors (APIs?, cameras?, microphones?) and hit Run.
author: @cmw3737

comment: at 19:00 - there is the discussion on the iterative approach which I fully understand and support. However, at what moment can you decide that there is a "final version". And what is true/accurate?  People already use ChatGPT and consider the output for 'truth'.  There's a dichotomy in building the model and the application of the output. A lot of the reasoning of Sam feels cherrypicking arguments pro and discarding the risks. History will teach us I suppose..

author: @HPUSER-sl2ht

comment: As a software developer/architect, I'm looking forward for the time where I can make only architectural decisions and AI can play the role of code monkey that implements the functions/methods for my design. I'd definitely do code review for every single line that the AI emits but I have no need to be the one that writes every line of code as long as the AI can emit code of high enough quality. I'm already trusting my collegues to write code and it rarely ends up the same I would have written but as long as it's readable, understandable and executes with high enough runtime performance, I'll accept the code. That said, I do complete code review for the code of my human collegues, too. And they verify my code, too.

author: @treasurehuntingusa1

comment:
Great conversation! It feels like we're in the "yahoo messenger" age of AI, where a lot is yet to be discovered and the language models need to mature to higher degree of intelligence.

One thing that I'm sceptical about is emotionless AI assisting human decisions in not so distant future. As masters, we'd like to use these tools to make intelligent decisions and handle mundane tasks for us with the right mix of IQ and EQ. For instance, while AI is shopping for us, buying milk could be low priority than buying meds even though a pack of milk might be logically cheaper than buying meds on a flexible budget. We'd like for AI to take an intelligent yet cognitive decision.

Maybe AGI will have such capabilities as per the description of it.
author: @karansethi7820

comment:
Interesting question at around 1:02:08 -- How much of the AGI is the interface, versus the wisdom contained in the tables?  

Essentially, it's a question of, suppose you have an absolute genius who has incredible knowledge or innovations in his head, but is incapable of communicating his ideas to other humans?

My prime example of the best case scenario is Shakespeare:  his knowledge, his wisdom regarding human nature and the human condition was miraculous.  And then, he somehow had an equally miraculous ability to CONVEY his thoughts and his understanding to other people.
